practice_cycles.focus_summary: Foundations of Resource Management and Syntax
practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase establishes your foundational understanding of the C++ syntax and memory management paradigms, which are critical because mastering these low-level concepts early on prevents the accumulation of technical debt that often leads to frustration or project failure as your codebases grow in complexity and scale during subsequent stages of your own professional development journey ahead.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Implementing custom data structures (linked lists, vectors) with manual heap allocation.
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Refactoring code to use smart pointers and observing scope-based lifetime changes.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Basic control flow and class definitions.
difficulty_profile.challenging: Correctly managing pointer ownership and avoiding memory leaks.

objective: Zero memory leaks reported by Valgrind on weekly exercises.
Successful implementation of a move-only resource class.
subjective: Confidence in identifying potential double-free errors.
Clarity on the difference between stack and heap allocation.

practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase transitions your focus toward high-level abstractions like templates and the Standard Template Library because your ability to leverage these tools effectively determines how well you can write reusable, efficient, and maintainable code without reinventing the wheel every time you encounter a common data structure or algorithmic problem in your sophisticated software projects during development.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Building generic algorithms using templates and the STL iterator interface.
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Analyzing the time complexity and overhead of different STL containers.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Using basic STL containers like std::vector and std::map.
difficulty_profile.challenging: Writing variadic templates and understanding SFINAE or Concepts.

objective: Implementation of a generic sort algorithm that works on multiple container types.
Reduced lines of code by replacing manual loops with STL algorithms.
subjective: Feeling comfortable deciphering template-related compiler errors.
Intuition for which container to select based on access patterns.

objective: Code compilation success rate without immediate runtime crashes.
Completion of exercises with zero warnings under -Wall and -Wextra flags.
Pass rate of automated unit tests on practice projects.
subjective: Self-rated clarity of the logic when reviewing code after one week.
Reduction in the number of times documentation is checked for basic syntax.

architect_notes: The jump from beginner to advanced in C++ requires a shift from 'how to write it' to 'how it works under the hood'.
Manual memory management is treated as a core skill to build intuition, even if modern C++ prefers smart pointers.
The 11-hour weekly commitment allows for deep work sessions which are necessary for debugging template errors.

details.reason: User initiated a new learning session.

timeline.title: Initial Practice Strategy Created
timeline.summary: Initial practice strategy created for ['Learn C++'].

details.reason: Sufficient information provided to create initial practice system.

constraints.dropout_risk: High complexity regarding manual memory management and template syntax
